reviewText: This is a game where you sit down, play for and 30 minutes to an hour, beat, then never play again. There's nothing wrong with that, but that is what this game is. Is it worth the 3 dollar price tag? For most people, probably not. My biggest problem with the game was that it was never challenging. A few rooms took a fair amount of time to beat, but they didn't test skill but were more trial and error and lucky bounces. I would also like to point out that the achievements are bugged, but that's really not going to be a problem unless you're achievement hunting.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Amazing Game. Worth all my 3 bucks. My only wish is that it was longer. I had completed the game, got every achievement, star, hidden star, everything. You should make a sequel and make it longer plz. Great game tho!

reviewText: Super Goo Goo is, admitedly, the sort of game I'm drawn to. That being said, it's also the sort of game I expect great things from. Though I would not call it great (at least not yet) I have to admit that I am enjoying it quite a bit.\n\nThe controls couldn't be simpler. Just point the curser where you wish Goo Goo"
recommended: to jump to. The game even offers a trajectory trace to make things less frustrating. The walls the "Goo Goo" hits react differently. Some stick
hoursPlayed: some reflect explosively. Most do nothing. A pretty cool little game for the price
helpfulPercent: and quite possibly the MOST deadly game I've ever played. I'm not sure it's possible to die more quickly or frequently than this game demands. This game offers dozens (if not hundreds) of tiny little puzzles to navigate the many rooms in the huge.......building? Fortunately
votesHelpful: a detailed map is provided for a simple RMB (right mouse button.) Some puzzles are very clever
votesTotal: none are just so stupid you want to walk away. And I must admit on occasion I have just laughed...out...LOUD!\n\nThe first 2 bosses are possibly the easiest I've seen in gaming (once I figured out that's even what they were.) I just realized I've neglected to mention the point of this game! Well
votesFunny: actually the point is just to cruise
column16: but in that process you accumulate stars. Certain numbers of stars are necessary to pass through some of the "wormholes" to the other rooms. While the rooms share similarities
column17: they also share a great numbers of original & creative surprises. Cruising is emphased by the need to return to rooms to find stars that were not noticed
column19: on first traverse. Keys must also be found to open certain rooms.\n\nArtistically this could easily be called "the South Park" of games. Having an artistic center of such extreme simplicity
column22: do grow annoying. And I think I might have been happier

column25: whatever it may be. Nothing except a clanky piano sounds much like music. As it says on the Store Page "All the sounds were made by his mouth(!!!)" Golly.\n\nUnfortunately
column26: so far there is just about ZERO community for this game. Not enough info was even available for several days to even generate anything vaguely statistical about the achievements. I feel sure that's a situation that will change. Although

reviewText: Once you get to this low of a price tag it is hard to really judge a game correctly. If you look a various mobile game review sites a lot of them are more descriptions of what the games are than an actual opinion, other than maybe: I guess it was fun". It is not easy to approach small games
date: mostly because of the simplicity that they bring. Super Goo Goo might as well have been a top tier Newgrounds Flash game or a mobile game
hoursPlayed: that is not an insult.\n\nWhat first drew me to Super Goo Goo was the extremely minimalistic sales pitch. "Eh
votesFunny: here we go!" And that actually tells a lot about the tone of the game and the way to approach it. It isn't a grand adventure. The developers (probably) knew that this would be just a small time waster. I completed the game 100% in a little under an hour and was only challenged in a few certain spots
commentsCount: but I remember overall enjoying the experience.\n\nThe game has a simple premise. You click the ball of goo
column16: and then you drag it like a slingshot and release and then you look at that little puddle of snot fly across the screen like you were a substitute teacher in a very rough pre-school. You will do this in a small open world
column17: made of a few dozen rooms accessed by portals. You then collect stars
column18: and special green stars that only appears when you're close to them
column19: and you use these stars to go through certain portals that has a star requirement. There are a good few extra gameplay elements like spikes
column20: platforms that you can stick to
column22: gravity and stuff like that. There is a mostly easy to follow map
column23: and right from the get go the game is about exploration.\n\nI'd like to point out that the sound aspect of Super Goo Goo is made singlehandedly by one guy just saying the effects. It's all done orally and it's pretty funny
column24: although the teleportation sound got a bit grating. It's also the same guy who made the music. It's a cute little old Midi-inspired soundtrack (if you've played "An Untitled Story"
column26: and it feels like it serves it purpose well enough.\n\nI really like the concept of a small scale open world game. One where you can get an easy overview and not feel like that it has been bloated. This might be an extreme case on the other side of the spectrum but it's nice to get some change from games like AAA sandboxes that tries to be bigger than they really are. What Super Goo Goo lacks in size and scale it delivers in genuinely great level design
column28: and just a beautifully relaxed nature. It could have been released for free
column29: but when you get down to just three bucks it starts to be a matter of penny-pinching in my opinion. Even if the game was terrible (which it wasn't) the only real reaction it will get from me would be: "Well
column31: I'll manage." But since it was actually a good game that gave me entertainment I think the three small bucks is well-given out. People pay five times as much to go to the cinema
column32: getting entertained for 1-3 hours and then those fifteen bucks are gone. I can play this game as much as I want. If anything I'm just happy that those three bucks I gave is now in the hands of people I can trust to make a fine product
column33: and that is just as much as big as a satisfaction as playing the game itself. Take a look at the screenshots and the description. Does an hour of dragging and shooting some goo through a small open world
column36: some not sound like fun? If it does
column37: pick it up and maybe you'll be amused for an hour too. And maybe you'll feel the satisfaction of supporting and advertising for Dumb and Fat Games since they (judging by the company name
column39: and overall quietness) refuse to do it themselves."

reviewText: First review:\nI will be honest, this game is just like a mobile game, a clone in fact. The sound effects they have are pretty annoying, and the sound when you click the mouse sounds like some hocking a spit wad up. The map is super hard to navigate, and I got lost even though they give a map.  If you like childish, boring, and repetitive mobile games, then this one is for you, I guess. No need to get this unless you want to waste 3 dollars on a game that should be FREE.
